name: Race, Nation, and the Enemy
long_desc: Conflicts over racial and national identity continue to dominate headlines in the United States as they often have during the nations history, from debates regarding the immigration, naturalization, and birthright citizenship of racial minorities to debates regarding racial disparities in access to civil rights. This course explores the discursive practices through which racial and national identities are formed and the frequent conflicts between them, particularly by focusing on the role of enemies, threats to the nation, and sacrifices made on behalf of the nation in American public discourse. Alongside primary sources of public discourse regarding wars, the immigration and citizenship of racial minorities, racial segregation and civil rights, and the criminal prosecutions of dissidents during periods of crisis, we will read secondary sources offering multiple theoretical and disciplinary approaches to the study of racial and national identity formation. Along with regular brief responses to readings, assignments will include a short rhetorical analysis paper and a longer research paper.

custom_fields.goals: Identify and analyze commonly occurring discursive practices used to construct racial and national identities at their intersection Produce and support a rhetorical analysis of one or more primary sources regarding the relationship between racial and national identity formation in a particular social, historical, and intellectual context, or potentially a comparison of two contexts Develop skills of critical analysis, research, and writing of academic research
custom_fields.key_topics: Rhetorical functions of enemy construction; demagoguery; racial and national identity; immigration and citizenship; racial segregation; civil rights; wartime rhetoric and war memorials.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Along with regular brief responses to readings, assignments will include a short rhetorical analysis paper and a longer research paper.
custom_fields.learning_resources: All readings are provided electronically on Canvas.
